nodes.text: Whereas the balance sheet shows the firm’s assets and liabilities at a given point in time, the income statement shows the flow of revenues and expenses generated by those assets and liabilities between two dates.
shows Global’s income statement for 2019 and 2018. We examine each category on the statement.

config.activityTitle: Global Corporation’s Income Statement Sheet for 2019 and 2018

nodes.text: The first two lines of the income statement list the revenues from sales of products and the costs incurred to make and sell the products. Note that in accounting, the terms
are equivalent. Net sales is simply gross sales minus any returns, discounts, and allowances. We will simply use the term
from here forward. The third line is
The third line of an income statement that represents the difference between a firm’s sales revenues and its costs.
, the difference between sales revenues and the cost of sales.

The next group of items is operating expenses. These are expenses from the ordinary course of running the business that are not directly related to producing the goods or services being sold. They include administrative expenses and overhead, salaries, marketing costs, and research and development expenses. The third type of operating expense, depreciation and amortization (a charge that captures the change in value of acquired assets), represents an estimate of the costs that arise from wear and tear or obsolescence of the firm’s assets.

Only certain types of amortization are deductible as a pretax expense (e.g., amortization of the cost of an acquired patent). Amortization of goodwill is not a pretax expense and is generally included as an extraordinary item after taxes are deducted.
It is not an actual cash expense. The firm’s gross profit less its operating expenses is called
A firm’s gross profit less its operating expenses.

We next include other sources of income or expenses that arise from activities that are not the central part of a company’s business. Cash flows from the firm’s financial investments are one example of other income that would be listed here. After we have adjusted for other sources of income or expenses, we have the firm’s earnings before interest and taxes, or
A firm’s earnings before interest and taxes are deducted.
From EBIT, we deduct the interest paid on outstanding debt to compute Global’s pretax income, and then we deduct corporate taxes to determine the firm’s net income.
Net income represents the total earnings of the firm’s equity holders. It is often reported on a per-share basis as the firm’s
A firm’s net income divided by the total number of shares outstanding.
, which we compute by dividing net income by the total number of shares outstanding:

data.alt: EPS equals StartFraction Net Income Over Shares Outstanding EndFraction equals StartFraction Number dollar sign 2 period 0 million Over 3.6 million shares EndFraction equals Number dollar sign 0 period 5 6 per share

nodes.text: Although Global has only 3.6 million shares outstanding as of the end of 2019 (from
), the number of shares outstanding may grow if Global has made commitments that would cause it to issue more shares. Consider these two examples:
Suppose Global compensates its employees or executives with
The right to buy a certain number of shares of stock by a specific date at a specific price.

that give the holder the right to buy a certain number of shares by a specific date at a specific price. If employees “exercise” these options, the company issues new stock and the number of shares outstanding would grow.
The number of shares may also grow if the firm issues
Corporate bonds with a provision that gives the bondholder an option to convert each bond owned into a fixed number of shares of common stock.
, a form of debt that can be converted into shares of common stock.
In the cases of stock options and convertible bonds, because there will be more total shares to divide the same earnings, this growth in the number of shares is referred to as
An increase in the total number of shares that will divide a fixed amount of earnings.
. Firms disclose the potential for dilution from options they have awarded by reporting
The earnings per share a company would have based on the total number of shares including the effects of all stock options and convertible bonds.

, which shows the earnings per share the company would have if the stock options were exercised. For example, if Global has awarded options for 200,000 shares of stock to its key executives, its diluted EPS is
